title: 110_hr2165
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teri Zenner Social Worker Safety Act". Congress finds that 2 million American workers are victims of job-related violence annually, with a significant portion occurring in the healthcare and social services fields. A study revealed that 70% of front-line child welfare workers have experienced violence. Front-line child welfare workers often face violence or threats in their line of duty. Exit interviews show that 90% experienced verbal threats, 30% faced physical attacks, and 13% were threatened with weapons. Social service workers in the public sector are 7 times more likely to be victims of violent assaults compared to those in the private sector. Some states and organizations have developed safety programs and guidelines for social workers and case workers. Social workers and case workers face job-related violence, impacting individuals, families, clients, and communities in the United States. There is a need to increase awareness and prevent such violence to protect these dedicated individuals and reduce the severity of injuries sustained. SEC. 3. SOCIAL WORKER SAFETY GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can award grants to States for safety measures for social workers and professionals working with at-risk populations. Funds can be used for safety equipment, training, facility improvements, and pepper spray for self-defense. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can award grants to States for safety measures for social workers and professionals working with at-risk populations. This includes providing pepper spray for self-defense, cultural competency training, de-escalation strategies, mental health training, educational resources on safety measures, and other activities determined by the Secretary. States must submit an application with required information to receive the grant. Each grant application must describe agencies receiving funding, activities for assistance, and evaluation of safety measures. Priority is given to applicants with the greatest need and those assisting multiple agencies. The Secretary ensures quality assurance and cost-effectiveness in grant awards. The Secretary establishes guidelines for cost-effective and quality safety measures funded under this section. Technical assistance may be provided to grant recipients for planning and implementing safety measures. States receiving grants must report on activities funded, training opportunities for social workers, and strategies to address threats to social workers' safety. The non-Federal share for safety measures in State grants is 50 percent. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 for this Act.
